name: Abate
fullDefinition: To become less intense or widespread (Typically of something perceived as hostile, threatening, or negative).
useSentence: The rain finally began to abate, and we saw a glimpse of sunlight.

name: Ambivalence
fullDefinition: The state of having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something or someone.
useSentence: His ambivalence made it difficult to choose between the two desserts on the menu.

name: Analogous
fullDefinition: Similar in a way that invites comparison : showing an analogy or a likeness that permits one to draw an analogy.
useSentence: The fall of Rome is analgous to our present situation!

name: Bereft
fullDefinition: lacking something needed, wanted, or expected
useSentence: Her room was stark and bereft of color.

name: Cognizant
fullDefinition: having knowledge or being aware of.
useSentence: Statesmen must be cognizant of the political boundaries within which they work.

name: Disrepute
fullDefinition: state of low public esteem
useSentence: Behaviour like this brings the entire industry into disrepute.

name: Acumen
fullDefinition: The ability to make good judgments and quick decisions, typically in a particular domain
useSentence: He will need all his political acumen in these negotiations

name: Impinge
fullDefinition: have an effect or impact, especially a negative one
useSentence: Mobile technology makes it easier for work to impinge on family life

name: Pejorative
fullDefinition: having negative connotations
useSentence: Most of what he said was inflammatory and filled with pejoratives.

name: Phlegmatic
fullDefinition: Self-controlled; calm and stoic.
useSentence: Even the normally phlegmatic Commander was grinning like a maniac..

name: Predilection
fullDefinition: A predisposition in favor of something
useSentence: She has a predilection for Asian food.

name: Terse
fullDefinition: sparing in the use of words; abrupt.
useSentence: 'No.' was his terse response

name: Fortuitous
fullDefinition: happening by a lucky chance; fortunate.
useSentence: This would have been impossible but for one fortuitous circumstance.

name: Loquacity
fullDefinition: talkativeness, esp. when excessive.
useSentence: Steve, who knew his son's tendency toward unnecessary loquacity as well as I did, replied for him.

name: Panoply
fullDefinition: an exravagant display or impressive collection of things.
useSentence: All the panoply of Western religious liturgy

name: Perspicacity
fullDefinition: Keenness of mental perception and understanding.
useSentence: Drinking heavily had distracted his watchfulness and obscured his perspicacity.

name: Praxis
fullDefinition: Accepted practice or custom.
useSentence: She is interested in both the theory and praxis of criminology.

name: Indefatigable
fullDefinition: Incapable of being tired out; not yielding to fatigue.
useSentence: An indefatigable defender of human rights.

name: Chagrin
fullDefinition: disquietude or distress caused by humiliation, disappointment, or failure.
useSentence: An indefatigable defender of human rights.

name: Bovine
fullDefinition: Having to do with cows or cattle. as pejorative; dull, dim-witted
useSentence: He had a gentle, slightly bovine expression.

name: Simian
fullDefinition: Relating to, resembling, or affecting apes or monkeys.
useSentence: A polymerase chain reaction analysis for simian virus 40 DNA was negative.

name: Sycophant
fullDefinition: A servile self-seeking flatterer.
useSentence: His high-rank attracts all sorts of sycophants

name: Superfluous
fullDefinition: Unnecessary, especially through being more than enough.
useSentence: Delete the superfluous details.

name: Irascible
fullDefinition: Having or showing a tendency to be easily angered.
useSentence: That house belongs to an irascible crank who never has a kind word for any neighbor.
